items.def: User Datagram Protocol, connectionless transport used for real time media and gaming; pros: low overhead, low latency; cons: no reliability or ordering; example: VoIP, DNS queries

Transmission Control Protocol, connection oriented reliable byte stream; pros: ordered delivery, congestion and flow control; cons: extra RTT for handshake, head of line blocking; example: HTTPS, IMAP
Internet Protocol, best effort packet delivery across networks; provides addressing and fragmentation (v4 only), no reliability by itself
Internet Protocol version 4, 32 bit addresses, supports NAT and in router fragmentation; example block: 192.168.1.0/24
Internet Protocol version 6, 128 bit addresses, fixed header, no in router fragmentation, uses extension headers; aims to remove need for NAT; example: 2001:db8::1
Internet Control Message Protocol, reports network errors and diagnostics; example: Echo Request/Reply for ping, Time Exceeded for traceroute
Address Resolution Protocol, maps IPv4 to MAC on a LAN; broadcasts who has X, target replies with MAC; cache with timeout
Neighbor Discovery Protocol, IPv6 replacement for ARP and IPv4 Router Discovery; uses ICMPv6 NS, NA, RS, RA and multicast
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol, auto assigns IP, mask, gateway, DNS; DORA sequence: Discover, Offer, Request, Ack
Network Address Translation, rewrites private to public addresses at edge; conserves IPv4, breaks end to end and some protocols; inbound fixes: port forwarding, UPnP
Port Address Translation, many to one NAT that multiplexes flows by source ports; most common consumer NAT
Classless Inter Domain Routing, variable length prefixes like /20, enables aggregation and efficient allocation
Longest Prefix Match, router chooses route with most specific matching prefix; critical for overlapping routes
Maximum Transmission Unit, largest frame payload on a link; PMTUD used to avoid fragmentation
Maximum Segment Size, TCP option limiting payload per segment, typically MTU minus IP and TCP headers
Time To Live or Hop Limit, decremented by routers to prevent loops; 0 triggers ICMP Time Exceeded
Differentiated Services Code Point, 6 bit QoS field in IP header for traffic classification
Quality of Service, techniques to prioritize traffic, manage delay and loss; e.g., voice priority queues
Round Trip Time, time for a packet and its reply; impacts TCP throughput and HTTP latency
Local Area Network, limited geographic scope, Ethernet and Wi Fi common
Wide Area Network, connects sites across distances, uses ISP backbones, MPLS, VPNs
Autonomous System Number, unique ID for a routing domain used by BGP
Interior Gateway Protocol, routing within an AS; examples: OSPF, IS IS, RIP, EIGRP
Exterior Gateway Protocol, routing between ASes; example: BGP
Routing Information Protocol, distance vector, hop count metric, slow convergence; educational and small labs
Open Shortest Path First, link state IGP, Dijkstra, areas and LSAs, supports authentication and summarization
Intermediate System to Intermediate System, link state IGP used by many carriers, TLV based
Border Gateway Protocol, path vector between ASes over TCP, policy based route selection
Link State Advertisement, OSPF messages that flood topology info inside areas
Area Border Router, OSPF router that connects an area to the backbone and performs summarization
Autonomous System Boundary Router, OSPF router that injects external routes from other protocols or BGP
BGP attribute listing traversed AS sequence, used for loop prevention and path length preference
BGP attribute to prefer exit paths within an AS, higher is preferred
BGP attribute indicating egress router to reach a prefix, drives hot potato to closest exit
Multi Exit Discriminator, BGP hint for neighboring AS on preferred entry, lower is preferred
Shortest path first algorithm for link state routing; complexity about O(n^2) with simple data structures
Distance vector recurrence D(x,y)=min_v{c(x,v)+D(v,y)}, iterative neighbor exchange
Stateless Address Autoconfiguration for IPv6, host forms its address from router advertised prefix and interface ID
Path MTU Discovery, sender discovers smallest MTU along path, avoids fragmentation by adjusting packet size
Same IP on many nodes, routing delivers to nearest by topology; used by DNS roots and CDNs
One sender to one receiver addressing
One to many group delivery, IPv4 224.0.0.0/4, IPv6 ff00::/8
One to all on subnet, not present in IPv6 which uses multicast instead
Fully Qualified Domain Name, absolute domain name ending with root dot, e.g., [www.example.com](http://www.example.com).
Top level domain, .com .org .net country codes like .us .uk
Record cache lifetime, balances performance and staleness risk
IPv4 address record, maps name to IPv4
IPv6 address record, maps name to IPv6
Canonical name alias, points name to another name, do not mix with other data
Name server record, delegates a zone to authoritative servers
Mail exchanger record, lists mail servers with preference values
Pointer record, reverse DNS mapping from IP to name
Start of Authority, zone metadata, primary NS, serial, timers
Service locator, host and port for named services, e.g., _sip._tcp.example.com
Text record, arbitrary text, often SPF or verification tokens
DNSSEC public key record for a zone
DNSSEC signature over RRsets, validated with DNSKEY
Delegation Signer, parent zone points to child DNSSEC key hash
DNSSEC next secure, lists next name and existing types, enables authenticated denial
Hashed variant of NSEC to prevent zone walking
DNS flag, 0 for query, 1 for response
DNS flag, authoritative answer bit set by auth servers
DNS flag, message truncated due to size
DNS flag, recursion desired by client
DNS flag, recursion available by server
DNSSEC flag, data authenticated by resolver
DNSSEC flag, checking disabled by client
DNS response code, query completed successfully
Domain name does not exist
Server failure, often due to DNSSEC validation or upstream issues
Server refused to perform the operation, policy or ACL
Hypertext Transfer Protocol, stateless requests and responses over TCP, methods like GET POST, supports headers for caching and content negotiation
HTTP over TLS, adds confidentiality, integrity, server auth; uses TLS handshake before HTTP
Uniform Resource Locator, identifies a resource location and scheme, e.g., [https://example.com/path](https://example.com/path)
Uniform Resource Identifier, broader identifier concept, URL is a subset
Header selecting virtual host on a shared IP, mandatory in HTTP/1.1
HTTP header identifying client software, useful for analytics and workarounds
HTTP header that declares media type of payload, e.g., text/html, application/json
HTTP header controlling caches, e.g., max-age, no-store
Headers that create and send session tokens, enable state over stateless HTTP; security flags: Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite
HTTP method to retrieve a resource, safe and idempotent
HTTP method to submit data that changes server state, not idempotent
HTTP method like GET but headers only, used for cache validation and size checks
HTTP method to replace a resource at a target URI, idempotent
HTTP method to remove a resource, idempotent by spec
Path discovery tool, sends probes with increasing TTL, routers reply with ICMP Time Exceeded, final host replies Port Unreachable
Reachability and RTT tool using ICMP Echo Request and Echo Reply
Each layer wraps upper layer data with its own header, link may add trailer; enables modular forwarding
Transport delivers segments to correct socket via 4 tuple of addresses and ports
Distance vector loop mitigation, advertise route to a neighbor as infinite if neighbor is next hop for it
Do not advertise a route back out the interface on which it was learned, reduces loops
RFC 1918 private space 10.0.0.0/8, not routed on Internet, used behind NAT
127.0.0.0/8, host local testing, 127.0.0.1 common
169.254.0.0/16, APIPA when DHCP fails, not routed
fe80::/10, auto on every interface, needed for NDP and RA
fc00::/7, private IPv6 addressing inside sites, not globally routed
2000::/3, Internet routable addresses
ff00::/8, group communication, e.g., ff02::1 all nodes on link
::1, equivalent of 127.0.0.1
::, used before address assignment, never a destination
DNS service, UDP for queries, TCP for zone transfers and large answers
HTTP cleartext service
HTTPS over TLS
SMTP server to server transfer
Mail submission by clients with auth
POP3 mailbox retrieval
IMAP mailbox access
IMAPS IMAP over TLS
SSH secure remote shell and tunneling
NTP network time synchronization
DHCP server listen port
DHCP client listen port
Source IP, source port, destination IP, destination port identify a transport flow
Receiver window limits sender to prevent buffer overflow; sender respects advertised rwnd
Sender adapts rate using cwnd, slow start, congestion avoidance, fast retransmit and recovery
BGP policy to exit the AS at the closest egress to minimize internal cost, may increase end to end path length for outbound traffic
